body: This feature would be great for recursive-iterative models where the intermediate outputs are used as the input of the next iteration.
I think allowing inputs (from GPU memory) is supported already. @pranavsharma

Yes, you should be able to allocate inputs/outputs in GPU memory before calling Run(). The C API exposes a function called OrtCreateTensorWithDataAsOrtValue that creates a tensor with a pre-allocated buffer. It's up to you where you allocate this buffer as long as the correct OrtAllocatorInfo object is passed to this function.

Sweet, thanks for clarifying that. I also wonder if there is existing example for doing that? If not, I will just do some trial and error to figure it out.

Also, since GPU memory can be used for inputs and outputs, do you mind to update the [C API doc](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/master/docs/C_API.md#features) to remove the part about input can't be on GPU memory?
What about the outputs? Is it possible to specify that some of the returned outputs should not be transferred to CPU?
You can pre-allocate both inputs and outputs on the GPU. Sorry, we don't have example code.
If outputs also need to be pre-allocated, then it is not possible to put variable-shape outputs into GPU directly, right? Since the size for outputs can only be determined after model run.

> If outputs also need to be pre-allocated, then it is not possible to put variable-shape outputs into GPU directly, right? Since the size for outputs can only be determined after model run.

yeah, you'll need to know the output shape apriori if you want to pre-allocate memory for them.

Could the GPU->CPU transfer be deferred until a call to _GetTensorMutableData_ is issued? Avoiding unnecessary transfers of intermediate results is critical for an efficient implementation of adaptive inference.
OrtGetTensorMutableData does not make any copies of the data. It simply returns a pointer to the underlying raw buffer in the tensor.

Yes, I am aware that _OrtGetTensorMutableData_ currently returns a pointer to the underlying buffer. 

I suggested delaying the GPU->CPU transfer until the output data is actually requested as a way of dealing with variable-shaped outputs whose layout cannot be determined beforehand. It has the advantage that it would not require changes in the interface, but any other alternative would be acceptable in order to have this feature.

@pranavsharma `OrtCreateTensorWithDataAsOrtValue` requires the `OrtAllocatorInfo` which describes where the data buffer is allocated, but I don't think the C APIs expose any GPU related allocator info. And I found nothing in the CUDA provider header files. How do I set this field properly?
You can use OrtCreateAllocatorInfo to create the gpu allocator info.

In the cases where the output tensors can be pre-allocated because their shapes can be determined beforehand they are still being transferred to CPU once the _OrtRun_ function finishes. Am I right? Is it possible to prevent this?

If the output OrtValue is created with a cuda allocator and the last node in the graph runs on the GPU, no copy to CPU will take place; the output will be placed on the GPU. I'll try to come up with some sample code that you can use.
Great! This will save unnecessary GPU-CPU round trips when doing adaptive inference. Please let us know when the sample code is available. Thanks!

@xgirones sorry, i missed one thing. Even though we've the API to create a tensor using any allocator (CreateTensorAsOrtValue), currently we don't have a public API to expose the allocator instance of the execution provider you're using as part of the session (in this case cuda). The only allocator we expose is the default CPU allocator. We'll add this to our roadmap.
@pranavsharma thanks for the information, can I conclude that currently GPU I/O is not public accessible because the C API hasn't exposed the GPU memory allocator / allocator info?

> @pranavsharma thanks for the information, can I conclude that currently GPU I/O is not public accessible because the C API hasn't exposed the GPU memory allocator / allocator info?

Yeah.
Thanks. Will it be possible to access the underlying device memory (pointer, strides) in case we need to run some CUDA kernels on it?

> Thanks. Will it be possible to access the underlying device memory (pointer, strides) in case we need to run some CUDA kernels on it?

The C API doesn't expose access to any specific device memory. Didn't fully understand your question though.
I would like to take advantage of the fact that the output is already in device memory to do further processing on the device without doing unnecessary GPU-CPU-GPU round trips.

How would this same concept translate to the C# API?

I am interested in passing data already in the GPU into a DL network with the output still residing in the GPU to be passed to the next element in a pipeline. If possible I’d like to do this without having to perform CPU/GPU copies. Is this possible at the moment?
I also need this features,      Will the next version be available？ thanks.
I need this feature too ... preferably mapping the Input/Output to a OpenCL Memory

This issue has been automatically marked as stale due to inactivity and will be closed in 7 days if no further activity occurs. If further support is needed, please provide an update and/or more details.
This issue has been automatically closed due to inactivity. Please reactivate if further support is needed.
Please open this issue back up. It's still a highly-desired feature and will be a performance bottleneck for some models until appropriate additions have been made to the API.
Does this feature supported?
Is there sample code to use IOBindings get input from cuda buffers?
